headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to this Exxon Mobil Corporation Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations and Secret
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to this Exxon Mobil Corporation Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations and Secretary, Mr. Jeff Woodbury. Please go ahead.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, good morning. And welcome to ExxonMobil's fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings call. My comments this morning will refer to the slides that are available through the investors section of our website. Further, I w
componenttext:
Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, good morning. And welcome to ExxonMobil's fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings call. 
My comments this morning will refer to the slides that are available through the investors section of our website. 
Further, I would like to draw your attention to our cautionary statement shown on Slide 2. 
Now turning to Slide 3. Let me begin by summarizing the key headlines of our performance. ExxonMobil generated full year earnings of $16.2 billion and fourth quarter earnings of $2.8 billion. These results reflect proven strategies that we consistently applied for decades, along with a relentless focus on the business fundamentals, including project, execution and effective cost management. 
While our Upstream financial results reflect the challenging business environment, stronger performance in our Downstream and Chemical segments highlights the resilience of our integrated businesses. 
ExxonMobil completed 6 major Upstream projects during the year. These new developments in Canada, Indonesia, Norway, United States and West Africa, added 300,000 oil-equivalent barrels per day of working interest production capacity and contributed 3.2% volumes growth. 
Strong operating performance of today's portfolio, along with these project conditions, delivered full year production of 4.1 million oil-equivalent barrels per day, consistent with our plans. 
The corporation's 2015 cash flow from operations and asset sales were $32.7 billion, with positive free cash flow of $6.5 billion despite sharply lower crude oil and natural gas prices. 
Moving to Slide 4. We provide an overview of some of the external factors affecting our results. Global economic growth continued to slow during the fourth quarter across nearly all major economies. In the U.S., estimates show growth softening further since the third quarter. In Asia, China continued to decelerate significant blow volatility in the financial sector. And Japan experienced ongoing economic weakness. Whereas, Europe's economy remains stable, with continued temperate growth. 
Crude oil prices extended declines on global oversupply conditions and natural gas prices moved lower, reflecting unseasonably warm weather through the quarter. 
Furthermore, global refining in Chemical margins weakened due to lower seasonal fuels demand and decreased chemical realizations. 
Turning now to the financial results shown on Slide 5. As indicated, fourth quarter earnings were $2.8 billion or $0.67 per share. Corporation distributed $3.6 billion to shareholders in the quarter through dividends and share purchases to reduce shares outstanding.  Of that total, $500 million were used to purchase shares. 
CapEx was $7.4 billion, down more than $3 billion from our fourth quarter 2014 as a result of ongoing capital efficiencies, market savings, reduced activity and timely project delivery. 
Cash flow from operations and asset sales was $5.1 billion, and at the end of the quarter, cash totaled $3.7 billion and debt was $37.8 billion. 
The next slide provides more detail on sources and uses of cash. Total for the quarter, cash decreased from $4.3 billion to $3.7 billion. Earnings, adjusted for depreciation expense, changes in working capital and other items and our ongoing asset management program yielded $5.1 billion of cash flow from operations and asset sales. 
The cash decrease from working capital changes includes both normal seasonality as well as the effect of the decline in crude prices on account balances and receivables and payables. 
Uses included not investments in the business of $6 billion and shareholder distributions of $3.6 billion. Cash flows were balanced over the quarter by increasing short term borrowing by about $4 billion. 
Moving on to Slide 7 for a review of our segment of results. ExxonMobil's fourth quarter earnings decreased $3.8 billion from a year ago quarter. Lower Upstream earnings were partially offset by stronger Downstream results, whereas decreased Chemical earnings were mostly offset by lower corporate and financing costs. 
In the sequential comparison shown on Slide 8, earnings decreased $1.5 billion due to lower earnings across all business segments. 
On average, corporate and financing expenses are anticipated to be $500 million to $700 million per quarter over the next few years. 
Turning now to the Upstream financial and operating results starting on Slide 9. Fourth quarter Upstream earnings were $857 million, down $4.6 billion from a year ago quarter, sharply lower commodity prices reduced earnings by more than $3.7 billion. 
Crude realizations declined more than $30 per barrel and gas was down $2.76 per 1,000 cubic feet. 
Favorable volume and mix affects increased earnings by $100 million. Volume additions from new developments were partly offset by regulatory restrictions in The Netherlands. All other items decreased earnings by $960 million, reflecting the absence of prior year impacts, including U.S. preferred income tax effects and the recognition of a favorable arbitration for appropriate assets in Venezuela. These were partially offset by lower operating costs. 
Moving to Slide 10. Oil-equivalent production increased 194,000 barrels per day or 4.8% compared to a year ago quarter. Liquids production was up almost 300,000 barrels per day or nearly 14% were ramp up of new development projects, work programs and entitlement effects were partly offset by fuel decline. 
Natural gas production decreased about 630 million cubic feet per day due to regulatory reduction restrictions in The Netherlands and fuel decline, partly offset by entitlement effects and development project volumes. 
Turning now to the sequential comparison starting on Slide 11. Upstream earnings decreased about $500 million from the third quarter. Lower realizations reduced earnings $840 million where crude prices were about $8 per barrel lower than the third quarter and natural gas prices were down $0.40 per 1,000 cubic feet. Volume and mix affects increased earnings $250 million, reflecting new project and work program growth, along with higher seasonal demand. All other items added $90 million driven by tax impacts. 
Upstream unit profitability for the fourth quarter was $2.26 per barrel, excluding the impact of noncontrolling interest volumes. 
Moving to Slide 12. Sequentially, volumes increased 330,000 oil-equivalent barrels per day or 8.4%. Liquid production was up 150,000 barrels per day, reflecting new project growth, work programs and entitlement effects. Natural gas production was 1.1 billion cubic feet per day higher in the third quarter, driven by stronger seasonal demand in Europe, entitlement effects and new project start-ups. 
Moving now to the Downstream financial operating results, starting on Slide 13. Downstream earnings for the quarter were $1.4 billion, up $854 million compared to the year ago quarter. Stronger margins and favorable volumes mix improved earnings by $610 million and $70 million, respectively. All other items increased earnings $170 million primarily driven by reduced maintenance activities and favorable foreign exchange and tax effects, partly offset by unfavorable inventory impacts. 
Turning to Slide 14. Sequentially, Downstream earnings decreased $682 million as lower margins reduced earnings by $860 million. Volume and mix effects increased earnings by $60 million, reflecting lower U.S. maintenance. Other items improved earnings by $120 million, primarily due to higher gains from asset sales, partially offset by unfavorable inventory effects. 
Moving now to the Chemical financial operating results starting on Slide 15. Fourth quarter Chemical earnings were $963 million, down $264 million compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. Weaker margins decreased earnings by $210 million, while favorable volumes and mix effects added $170 million due to lower maintenance. All other items decreased earnings by $230 million, largely due to unfavorable foreign exchange, inventory and tax effects. 
Moving to Slide 16. Chemical earnings were down $264 million sequentially. Weaker margins reduced earnings by $190 million, while favorable volumes mix added $80 million. 
Other items decreased earnings $160 million primarily reflecting increased maintenance activities. 
Turning now to the full year financial results, starting on Slide 17. Now as I mentioned, earnings were $16.2 billion or $3.85 per share. Corporation distributed over $15 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases to reduce shares outstanding, and of that total, $3 billion was used to purchase shares. 
CapEx total about $31 billion for the year, the reduction of almost $7.5 billion or 19% versus 2014 and approximately $3 billion below our plans for 2015.  Cash flow from operations and asset sales was $32.7 billion. 
Turning to Slide 18. Cash decreased from $4.7 billion to $3.7 billion during the year. Earnings adjusted for depreciation expense, changes in working capital and other items and our ongoing asset management program, resulted in $32.7 billion of cash flow from operations and asset sales. 
Uses included net investments of $26.2 billion and shareholder distributions of $15 billion. Debt and other financing items provided $7.6 billion in the year. 
Moving to Slide 19. Graphic illustrates the corporation sources and uses of cash during the year and highlights our ability to meet our financial objectives. Cash flow from operations and asset sales of $32.7 billion from its shareholder distributions and most of our net investments in the business, supplemented by an increase in debt financing. The investments we select have attractive financial returns and justified the moderate use of our strong balance sheet capacity. 
The scale and integrated nature of our cash flows, along with our financial strength, provide us the flexibility and confidence to invest through the commodity price cycle to meet long-term energy demand. 
Corporation has continued to pay a reliable and growing dividend, directly sharing the corporation's success with our shareholders. 
Total dividends per share is $2.88 are up 6.7% versus 2014. As you know, we prudently tapered the share buyback program during 2015, consistent with changes in the business environment and the corporation's cash requirements. 
In the first quarter of 2016, ExxonMobil will limit share purchases to amounts needed to offset dilution related to our benefit plans and programs, and we do not plan on making additional purchases to reduce shares outstanding. 
During 2015, ExxonMobil generated $6.5 billion of free cash flow, reflecting our cost and capital discipline and the resilience of our integrated business model. 
Looking forward, we anticipate capital and exploration expenditures to be $23.2 billion in 2016, a decrease of almost $8 billion or 25% from 2015. 
So to summarize this slide, the corporation finished the year with positive free cash flow. We have significantly lowered our capital spending plans and are aggressively pursuing operating efficiencies and cost-savings as we continue to ramp up production from our major projects, all of which will support cash flow moving forward. We will provide further details on our investment plans market our upcoming Analyst Meeting. 
Moving now to Slide 20 and a review of our full year segmented results. 2015 earnings decreased $16.4 billion as weaker Upstream results were partially offset by stronger Downstream performance and lower corporate costs. 
Turning now to the full year comparison of Upstream results, starting on Slide 21. Upstream earnings of $7.1 billion were $20.4 billion lower than 2014. Realizations reduced earnings by $18.8 billion as crude oil prices declined more than $45 per barrel and natural gas dropped about $2.50 per 1,000 cubic feet. 
Favorable volume mix effects increased earnings $810 million for contributions to major project start-ups for the last couple of years as well as our work program activities, partially offset by the impact of regulatory restrictions in The Netherlands and field decline. All other items decreased earnings by $2.4 billion. Lower gains on asset sales and absence of prior year deferred income tax effects were partly offset by lower operating expenses. 
Upstream unit profitability for the year was $4.89 per barrel, excluding the impact of noncontrolling interest volumes. This reflects significantly lower commodity prices, partially offset by asset hydrating, including the start-up of new development projects. 
Moving to Slide 22. As indicated, volumes ended the the year at 4.1 million oil-equivalent per day, up 3.2% compared to last year. Liquids production was up 234,000 barrels per day or 11%, benefiting from major projects in several countries, work programs and entitlements impacts, which were partly offset by fuel decline. 
Natural gas production, however, was down 630 million cubic feet per day as regulatory restrictions in The Netherlands and field decline were partly offset by additional major project volumes in Papua New Guinea and the U.S., along with higher entitlements. 
Full year comparison for Downstream results is shown on Slide 23. Earnings were $6.6 billion, an increase of $3.5 billion from 2014. Stronger refining and marketing margins increased earnings by $4.1 billion. Volume and mix effects, mainly driven by increased maintenance reduced earnings by $200 million. All other items decreased earnings by $420 million, reflecting higher maintenance activities and unfavorable inventory impacts, partly offset by favorable foreign exchange effects. 
On Slide 24, we show the full year comparison for Chemical results. 2015 earnings were $4.4 billion, up $103 million from 2014. Stronger margins increased earnings $590 million, while favorable volumes mix added $220 million due to lower maintenance. Other items reduced earnings $710 million, reflecting unfavorable foreign exchange, tax and inventory effects, partly offset by asset management gains. 
Moving next to an update on our Upstream project activities. We continue to deliver on our investment plans, which are adding higher value production capacity to meet long-term demand growth. 6 major projects start-ups in 2015 added nearly 300,000 oil-equivalent barrels per day of working interest capacity. We also progress development of our high-quality acreage in the Permian and Bakken at a measured pace, where drilling programs added 85,000 oil-equivalent barrels per day of gross production in 2015. 
In the fourth quarter, the Banyu Urip Central processing facility successfully started up. Current gross production is 150,000 barrels per day and continues to ramp up towards full capacity as we optimize both well and facility performance. 
Looking forward, construction activities continue to progress on 10 major projects that will come online over the next 2 years. We expect to start up 6 of those in 2016, which will add more than 250,000 barrels per day of working interest production capacity. 
Moving on to Slide 26. We continue to execute a paced and focused exploration program to deliver accretive value to ExxonMobil's asset portfolio, while capturing cost efficiencies in today's softer market. 
In offshore Guyana, the largest 3D seismic survey in the company's history, is nearly complete, and we will begin appraising the lease of discovery during the first quarter. 
We also acquired a 35% interest in operatorship for Canje Block, which is adjacent to the Stabroek Block, netting over 520,000 net acres. 
In the Romanian Black Sea, ExxonMobil has completed exploration activities in Neptune Block after successfully drilling 7 consecutive wells since July 2014. 
Based on the results of the program, including a successful wall protest of the Domino prospect, we are advancing detailed development planning and economic viability studies. 
And in Argentina, we are beginning a production pilot program on the La Invernada and Bajo del Choique blocks in the Neuquén province. Program consists of 5 wells along construction and production facilities and a gas pipeline. 
Over the past few months, we have also added high potential acreage to our diverse portfolio. ExxonMobil acquired a 35% interest in Block 14 offshore Uruguay, capturing almost 580,000 net acres. 
In Canada, we awarded interest in 3 blocks offshore Newfoundland and Labrador, adding over 650,000 net acres. These blocks are in prudent oil hydrocarbon basin with recent industry discoveries. And this new opportunity will build in our 18 years of success in Eastern Canada with Hibernia, Terra Nova and the ongoing development at Hebron. 
And in Western Canada, we acquired additional working interest and are currently producing Duvernay acreage, adding 10,000 net acres. 
So now I'd like to conclude today's comments with a summary of our 2015 performance, which demonstrates the resilience of our integrated business. ExxonMobil earned $16.2 billion, underpinned by the benefits of our integrated business model, which captures value through the cycle as demonstrated by our strong Downstream and Chemical results. 
Corporation achieved its full year plan to produce 4.1 million oil-equivalent barrels per day, drawing the contributions from a portfolio of new developments underscore our project execution excellence and reputation as a reliable operator. Our results also reflect a relentless focus to reduce cost. 
In 2015, we achieved about $11.5 billion in capital and cash operating cost reductions. 
Solid operating performance combined with continued investment and cost discipline generated cash flow from operations and asset sales of $32.7 billion and positive free cash flow of $6.5 billion. Our commitment to shareholders remains strong as demonstrated by our reliable and growing dividend. So regardless of industry conditions, we remain focused on what we can control and are driven to create shareholder value through the cycle. 
Now we will discuss our forward plans in more detail at our upcoming Analyst Meeting, which will take place at the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, March 2, with a live webcast beginning at 9:00 a.m. Eastern Time. That concludes my prepared remarks, and I would now be happy to take your questions.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And first to Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And first to Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, the CapEx cut is pretty material. I wonder if you could help us reconcile Exxon's fuel spending through the cycle with the extent of -- give some idea so maybe just clarify 2 things. Where -- is that really a function of the slowdown in the E&P spen
componenttext: Jeff, the CapEx cut is pretty material. I wonder if you could help us reconcile Exxon's fuel spending through the cycle with the extent of -- give some idea so maybe just clarify 2 things. Where -- is that really a function of the slowdown in the E&P spending that was already underway? And is it still include the minority of affiliate contribution, and I have a follow up, please?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, first, let me start with your second question first. The CapEx guidance that we provided for 2016 of $23.2 billion is all in. It includes consolidated and equity companies, and it compares directly with the $31.1 billion that we spent in 2015. To an
componenttext: Doug, first, let me start with your second question first. The CapEx guidance that we provided for 2016 of $23.2 billion is all in. It includes consolidated and equity companies, and it compares directly with the $31.1 billion that we spent in 2015. To answer your first question, I first like to say that, as I said, in my prepared comments, we were down in the year in 2015, both from 2014 performance as well as our planned guidance in 2015. And that was primarily a continued focus on capital efficiencies, market savings and soft business climate. There was reduced activity, and then importantly, timely project delivery. If you think about 2016, it's more of the same. It reflects our prudent cash management and our continued investment through this cycle in  attractive, high-quality opportunities that we believe will generate long-term shareholder value. The short of it is, we're going to continue to live within our means. We're going to maintain financial flexibility, and we've got as you heard us talk in the past, we've got a very diverse high-quality inventory investment opportunities that we'll continue to progress.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I assume that was one question and a couple pause. So my follow-up is, I realized you've been pretty tight with Guyana today. It's obviously beginning and that there is my understanding is have already started this up see survey, which suggest that the
componenttext: So I assume that was one question and a couple pause. So my follow-up is, I realized you've been pretty tight with Guyana today. It's obviously beginning and that there is my understanding is have already started this up see survey, which suggest that there was a production system scheme underway. Can you just give us a general update as to where things starting Guyana, whether there is indeed an earlier production system target on how you see the overall scale of the opportunity to the extent you can chat about at this point?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Doug. I clearly understand the industry interest in the discovery. As we said at the time of this call, we're very encouraged with the initial results recognizing that we only have one well in a very, very large block, over 6.5 million acres.
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Doug. I clearly understand the industry interest in the discovery. As we said at the time of this call, we're very encouraged with the initial results recognizing that we only have one well in a very, very large block, over 6.5 million acres. We have since the discovery move quickly to get a drill ship contracted and on site to appraise the discovery and we expect that despite very shortly. As I said, the seismic acquisition is nearing completion, the results from both the well as well as the seismic are being actively assessed to assess the full block potential as well as commercial viability of the lase of discovery. Obviously, the objective of the first well is appraisal well and it's intended to give us important information to size the resource as well as get a test on it to assess the key variables associated with the commercial viability. So I would tell you that there are early studies underway on potential development options for the field, but I don't have anything more to share on that.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Sam Margolin with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Sam Margolin with Cowen & Company.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the press release, you called out some of the project start-ups and would seem like a net overall favorable mix effect on income. I think that maybe Western Canada is included in the start-ups but not may be a contributor to mix income enhancements. Ca
componenttext: In the press release, you called out some of the project start-ups and would seem like a net overall favorable mix effect on income. I think that maybe Western Canada is included in the start-ups but not may be a contributor to mix income enhancements. Can you talk about Western Canada kind of their heavy levels of pressure we're seeing on the heavy oil out there and maybe frame an outlook for us?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I mean, no doubt, profitability is compressed in this price environment. As I have said before, we remain very focused on the fundamentals. And I'll tell you that the team there in Canada have gone an exceptional job in driving the cost structu
componenttext: Yes, sure. I mean, no doubt, profitability is compressed in this price environment. As I have said before, we remain very focused on the fundamentals. And I'll tell you that the team there in Canada have gone an exceptional job in driving the cost structure down, in enhancing reliability. We are not, by any means, where we want to be. In fact and by any means status quo. We will continue to work that, recognizing that we feel very good about the resource potential, not only in Kearl but in Western Canada and our portfolio. We think that over the long term, the asset is going to be high valued, the focus is around maintaining cash profit and maximizing long-term value in the asset.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And sort of in the other end of the spectrum, I guess, is LNG, which is considered by many investors to be cost prohibitive, but actually has a pretty low overhead once they're operating. Can you help us understand how that contributed this quarter and to
componenttext: And sort of in the other end of the spectrum, I guess, is LNG, which is considered by many investors to be cost prohibitive, but actually has a pretty low overhead once they're operating. Can you help us understand how that contributed this quarter and to the year, specifically with PNG and some of the positive income contributions there?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, Sam, it's a great question because LNG clearly is a key component of our portfolio, and it is an important part of our margin generation. Remember, we're constructive on long-term demand? Gas, as you saw the recent update on our energy outlo
componenttext: Sure. I mean, Sam, it's a great question because LNG clearly is a key component of our portfolio, and it is an important part of our margin generation. Remember, we're constructive on long-term demand? Gas, as you saw the recent update on our energy outlook, we get gas growing at about 1.6% per year. LNG is anticipated to triple between now and 2040, so we're very well poised to participate in that demand growth over the long term. I would tell you that PNG is a really good example. The initial design basis of PNG was about 6.9 million tons per annum. As we said in the third quarter, the organization did an exceptional job in doing what we do very well, and that is get more out of the asset, and we were able to get it up to in excess of 7.4 million tons per annum, which has been just a phenomenal result, and we're still going. So it's a good example of how we really continued to manage the existing assets, to reduce the cost structure and prove operational reliability to maximize long-term asset value.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Phil Gresh with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Phil Gresh with JPMorgan.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is just kind of bigger picture, macro question. Obviously, pricing has been top across all-in markets, oil, natural gas, LNG. I'm just curious if you see a fundamental supply/demand improvement happening in any one particular market versus
componenttext: First question is just kind of bigger picture, macro question. Obviously, pricing has been top across all-in markets, oil, natural gas, LNG. I'm just curious if you see a fundamental supply/demand improvement happening in any one particular market versus another over the next year or 2. So for example, do you see oil recovering faster than natural gas or anything else along those line?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I guess I have to say that we're price takers, and we manage the business to create margin through self help. Wherever we have built this business to ensure that it's durable in a low price environment. And then an excerpt from that is additional
componenttext: Yes. So I guess I have to say that we're price takers, and we manage the business to create margin through self help. Wherever we have built this business to ensure that it's durable in a low price environment. And then an excerpt from that is additional return on the investment. So the organization is very focused on really managing the fundamentals. As I indicated were -- for both gas and oil, we're construct on a long-term demand growth. And it's fundamental basis for the investment decisions that we put in place. And if you look near term, demand has been growing about 1 million-barrel per day per year and although supply has been growing at a higher rate, we certainly have, I mean, the first half of this year, we have about 1.5 million barrels per day in excess of demand. We expect that to converge in the second half as season demand increases. We got to come in balance, but we have seen historically, we do have a bit of a build up in crude storage that will have to be worked off before you see real growth in prices. But ultimately, we're going to manage wherever we are in the price cycle to create margin by focusing on the fundamentals. Same story around LNG is, as I said previously that we're very constructive on where LNG demand is going to go over from now to 2040.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. The second question is just on the capital spending guidance. Thanks for giving us the preview ahead of the Analyst Day. I guess, what I'm wondering was year-over-year, how much of that you might attribute to project roll off or deflatio
componenttext: Okay, understood. The second question is just on the capital spending guidance. Thanks for giving us the preview ahead of the Analyst Day. I guess, what I'm wondering was year-over-year, how much of that you might attribute to project roll off or deflationary benefit versus a reduction in activity. And just in general, you came in under the 2015 budget as you said. How much flexibility is there, do you think, relative to the guidance number versus that being past the lowest you could go?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I don't have specific numbers to quote with you. And as I said, we'll talk more about our investment plans and our thoughts on volumes next month in the Analyst Meeting. But a couple things to share with you. Clearly, our peak was back in 2013 at
componenttext: Yes, so I don't have specific numbers to quote with you. And as I said, we'll talk more about our investment plans and our thoughts on volumes next month in the Analyst Meeting. But a couple things to share with you. Clearly, our peak was back in 2013 at about $42.5 billion. The drop from 2013 to 2014 was primarily a result of a drop off on this very significant major project load that we decided to take on. Obviously, in every year, we are working on capital efficiency opportunities to build in to our spend pattern. As we go forward, I would tell you, right now, most of the drop is associated with the prudent cash management that we've got. It's not indicative of the quality of the portfolio. As I've said previously, our portfolio is very deep and diverse across the Upstream, Downstream and Chemical business. Some of the activity that we've slowed down really provides us an opportunity to rethink near-term investments and really fully capture the market benefits going forward. But short of that, I really don't have any more specifics to share as to breaking the CapEx spend down further. We'll continue to live within our means as we've shown historically. And if we need, we'll have to tighten up if we had to further.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you see some additional flexibility even relative to this guidance?
componenttext: So you see some additional flexibility even relative to this guidance?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got flexibility both ways.
componenttext: We've got flexibility both ways.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exxon is relatively unique in its ability and dedication to cash [indiscernible] spend. Can you discuss the decision to cut the buy back in that context? And is that reduction, any reflection on relative attracters to the portfolio, value of the stock or
componenttext: Exxon is relatively unique in its ability and dedication to cash [indiscernible] spend. Can you discuss the decision to cut the buy back in that context? And is that reduction, any reflection on relative attracters to the portfolio, value of the stock or a weaker macro outlook?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, we've got a very, as I said, a very deep and diverse portfolio. Much of that investment could be move forward in today's environment, but as I indicated, we have a real opportunity to go ahead and rethink some of those expenditure patterns and
componenttext: No. I mean, we've got a very, as I said, a very deep and diverse portfolio. Much of that investment could be move forward in today's environment, but as I indicated, we have a real opportunity to go ahead and rethink some of those expenditure patterns and catch more of value from those investments. So the decision to cut the buyback doesn't at all reflect the quality inventory. Quite the contrary. I mean, the inventory is very robust. Decision on the buyback, as we've said before, our capital allocation approach is really focused on the dual priority of finding attractive investments and continuing to provide a reliable and growing dividend. And the share buybacks has always been the flexible part of our capital allocation program. As we continue to progress in a very challenging business climate, you saw us prudently taper back the buyback program. We will continue to evaluate the buyback program on a quarterly basis depending on changes in the business as well as the investment climate and advice on a quarterly basis when we think it's -- when it's appropriate.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Maybe if I can shift gears into the U.S. You're currently running I think 7 rigs in the Bakken and 8 rigs in the Permian. I mean, maybe particular in the Bakken, what's the driver of continued activity at current prices? I mean is that are those ec
componenttext: Great. Maybe if I can shift gears into the U.S. You're currently running I think 7 rigs in the Bakken and 8 rigs in the Permian. I mean, maybe particular in the Bakken, what's the driver of continued activity at current prices? I mean is that are those economic wells or you're preserving efficiencies ultimately acceleration in a question for the Permian that might be HBP driven. Any color would be helpful.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, that's a good question because we have a very extensive well inventory on our  own conventional business particularly in the liquids place, the Permian, Bakken and Woodford Ardmore. Once again, it's a conscious decision to be measured in our in
componenttext: Yes, Evan, that's a good question because we have a very extensive well inventory on our  own conventional business particularly in the liquids place, the Permian, Bakken and Woodford Ardmore. Once again, it's a conscious decision to be measured in our investment program. When we saw the big ramp up in rigs back in 2014, 2015, we're very measured and how we ramp up because we wanted to ensure that we fully develop the learning curve and capture those real cost benefits that translate into higher value as we fully develop these fields. So the investments that we're making right now are economic, they are attractive in this business climate. We are maintaining a certain baseload of activity where we can continue to leverage some of the best service providers that we've got, one of the few that can continue to invest in the down cycle. We've high graded our -- all the services that we get in our own conventional business. In fact, I'd extend that globally, and we are continuing on those learning curves. And I think it just better positions us to maximize the value from these assets.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Doug Terreson with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll go next to Doug Terreson with Evercore ISI.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on Slides 25 and 26, you talked about the project portfolio and the growth trajectory longer term. Simultaneously though, when you consider that the growth is coming to extensive returns during the past cycle, not just for Exxon, but for the other supe
componenttext: So on Slides 25 and 26, you talked about the project portfolio and the growth trajectory longer term. Simultaneously though, when you consider that the growth is coming to extensive returns during the past cycle, not just for Exxon, but for the other super majors, too, it makes me wonder whether there should be more emphasis towards value creation especially when considering that the valuation for some of the bigger oil companies is pretty much at its lowest level the past 2 decades and in some cases, 3 decades. So my question is whether or not the issue instructed returns and growth are being revisited internally maybe more so than in the past? Or is that what is implied and a new spending outlook that's talked about today? And then also, whether or not returns on capital, which I didn't see mentioned in the presentation is still as relevant as it used to be. So 2 questions.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the first one, I mean your point on value-creation in our investment program, we couldn't agree with you more. And I would tell you that is our view has never changed on the importance of making about the right value choices. We saw back in the --
componenttext: Yes, on the first one, I mean your point on value-creation in our investment program, we couldn't agree with you more. And I would tell you that is our view has never changed on the importance of making about the right value choices. We saw back in the -- I'd say, in the early 2000s to the mid-2010 time frame, we saw a number of major Upstream projects that got to the point of maturity that we can make a investment decision and capture unique value by progressing such a large load of major Upstream investments. There were cost synergies that we were going to capture that ultimately was going to improve the long-term return of those assets. So we knew that by taking on such a large load, it was going to impact our return on capital employed because we would build up a very large load of nonproductive capital employed. But we also knew that when those projects came on stream that they were going to be accretive to our overall average financial performance. So unfortunately, as these projects are coming on, the price environment has changed for us. But nonetheless, we still feel very good about the long-term financial performance of these assets because remember, when we make the final investment decision, we're testing those investments across a wide range of economic parameters, including price. And as I said earlier, our fundamental focus is been making sure that our business is viable and durable in a low price environment. So ultimately, we believe that these 30 plus major Upstream projects that had an impact, rightfully so had an impact in our return on capital employed are going to be accretive to our financial performance over the long term, and we're able to make the right decision. Now to your second question, on capital employed, it is still very much relevant to us. We believe it is a fundamental measure that differentiates us, and that's why we continue to talk about it. We have never lost sight of the importance of that metric relative to the investment decisions that we're making.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Maybe it will be a returns and valuations and catch up and more normalized environment in the future then?
componenttext: Okay, great. Maybe it will be a returns and valuations and catch up and more normalized environment in the future then?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ed Westlake with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ed Westlake with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats on, obviously, $11.5 billion of capital and OpEx savings. OpEx, you haven't really spoken about as much this morning. Just maybe run through some of the actions you took to reduce OpEx over the course last year and then the potential of OpEx furt
componenttext: Congrats on, obviously, $11.5 billion of capital and OpEx savings. OpEx, you haven't really spoken about as much this morning. Just maybe run through some of the actions you took to reduce OpEx over the course last year and then the potential of OpEx further?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for that, Ed, because it is a very important story of our 2015 performance. First, let me just make sure you're going to understand the number that we've been talking about. The numbers are fully consistent with our external reporting so that
componenttext: Yes, thanks for that, Ed, because it is a very important story of our 2015 performance. First, let me just make sure you're going to understand the number that we've been talking about. The numbers are fully consistent with our external reporting so that you all have good line of sight. Of the $11.5 billion I mentioned, about $8.5 billion of it -- $1 billion of that is operating expenses. It then includes a number of things, positive and negative. For instance, it includes the structural efficiencies that we were able to capture. It includes the market savings that we've been able to capture. Remember I talked in the past about having a unique organization or global terminal organization, that's really focused on achieving the lowest life cycle costs. The number includes benefits in energy costs, includes benefits from our asset management program as well as ForEx. There are increases in that number. Obviously, we can talk about all these new projects coming on stream with incomes and increase in the operating costs and we'll continue to manage those assets like we do with our mature inventory. There was also a higher Downstream load on unplanned maintenance that added cost during the year. So simply put, the $8.5 billion is a year-on-year comparison. The rest, $3 billion, is in CapEx. It includes a lot of same actions I just talked about as well as decisions to slow down some activity to capture opportunities in this business climate. I will note that, that $3 billion only reflects the reduction from our claim guidance. As I said in the prepared comments, our year-on-year reduction of CapEx was $7.5 billion, so we didn't really include the $4.5 billion and the $11.5 billion that I talked about in the prepared comments. So in total, year-on-year, our total reduction is really $16 billion if you include the $4.5 billion.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then in terms the ability to drive further OpEx. I mean another 10%, another 15%, I mean, how low do you think you can get that to OpEx savings?
componenttext: Yes. And then in terms the ability to drive further OpEx. I mean another 10%, another 15%, I mean, how low do you think you can get that to OpEx savings?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, Ed. Really is because it really talks to the strength of the organization. In this low price environment, it presents opportunities, too. And the organization is never satisfied with the status quo. The organization is very focused
componenttext: It's a great question, Ed. Really is because it really talks to the strength of the organization. In this low price environment, it presents opportunities, too. And the organization is never satisfied with the status quo. The organization is very focused on leading that cost curve. And while we may have some internal stewardship objectives, rest assured, we continue to look for new, unique ways to capture structural improvements, which are most important. Remember, those are the ones that are going to be permanent going forward. So there's lot more to work on, but I don't have any specific numbers at this point.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could follow up on a comment that you made a couple of times now. You've talked about how you guys are rethinking return of investments as a way to deploy capital. How much does this refer to the evolution of your view on relative attractivenes
componenttext: Maybe if I could follow up on a comment that you made a couple of times now. You've talked about how you guys are rethinking return of investments as a way to deploy capital. How much does this refer to the evolution of your view on relative attractiveness upon varies components of the portfolio in terms of, is there represented at all a shift in attractiveness of onshore versus deepwater versus rich oil or LNG, et cetera? Or how much is just referring to rethinking the cost structure in the near-term environment and an effort to continue to push down prices?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really both. It's every investment dollar is competing. So it's all about how do we get the most value out of those investment dollars that are being deployed to that business. The organization, as I indicated, really views the down cycle as a real o
componenttext: It's really both. It's every investment dollar is competing. So it's all about how do we get the most value out of those investment dollars that are being deployed to that business. The organization, as I indicated, really views the down cycle as a real opportunity to go back and retest development concepts, retest the cost structures, retest the commercial terms and whether it's short cycle or long cycle, we're going to maintain that competitive focus and make the right value choices, coupled with our prudent cash management.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe just as a follow up on that. I mean, during the most recent downturn in '08, '09, you took advantage of the environment by pushing through more countercyclical investment in places like the Canadian oil sands and I think we all reali
componenttext: Great. And then maybe just as a follow up on that. I mean, during the most recent downturn in '08, '09, you took advantage of the environment by pushing through more countercyclical investment in places like the Canadian oil sands and I think we all realized that, that this downturn is different. But do you see similar opportunities to leverage your strength in this environment, either on the constant project involvement side or may be on other research acquisition side? Or is your outlook different than up at this point that you feel the more prudence is necessary in kind up in the short to medium term?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, clearly, given the uncertainty in prices, we're going to maintain prudency. But at the same time, as I've said a couple of times, Ryan, we really do see that this is an opportunity to capture further value in the bottom of the cycle across a
componenttext: Well, I mean, clearly, given the uncertainty in prices, we're going to maintain prudency. But at the same time, as I've said a couple of times, Ryan, we really do see that this is an opportunity to capture further value in the bottom of the cycle across all the areas I've already mentioned but there are plenty of opportunities at the organization is focused on to really make that value proposition. And I'd also add that because of our ability to invest through this cycle, our service provider's understand that they can provide, lower cost, higher value solutions to us then we'll continue to invest if it makes good business sense. So having, not only the organization focused on but also our service providers focused on it has provided some unique opportunities for us.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I'm looking forward to seeing you all at the analyst meeting. I know that [indiscernible] Stephen New York a couple of times -- I should say in New York and Miami making some statements. I haven't personally spoken to him since last March. The gener
componenttext: Jeff, I'm looking forward to seeing you all at the analyst meeting. I know that [indiscernible] Stephen New York a couple of times -- I should say in New York and Miami making some statements. I haven't personally spoken to him since last March. The general message that you have then was certainly that we would be lower for longer. I assume he's still making that argument. I think that he was saying that you guys would be typically keen to make acquisitions at the bottom of the cycle, but the bid off's spread will be too wide. He was saying less interested buying the balance sheet that was bad he was referred to buying a balance sheet that was good. I think you said the consolidation in the Permian would be an area of interest. Is that the latest message that we've got for example at the Miami conference? I'm sorry, I wasn't present. I was wondering if the message has changed.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I mean, from a supply/demand perspective, I shared some of our thoughts around expectations. Clearly, the oversupply currently and the overhang from storage is going to have a dampening effect on prices in the near term. But, Paul, as we've tal
componenttext: Yes. Well, I mean, from a supply/demand perspective, I shared some of our thoughts around expectations. Clearly, the oversupply currently and the overhang from storage is going to have a dampening effect on prices in the near term. But, Paul, as we've talked in the past, we continue to be focused on the fundamentals and through our self-help, creating margin, and that's was most important for this business. We invest to ensure that the business is durable, at low prices. We continue to manage the business based on our focus on the fundamentals to create margin. From an acquisition perspective, clearly, I'm sure there's a tremendous amount of interest. We remain very patient, we keep alert to the value propositions. But as I've said before, anything that we see out there has got to be competitive with our current investment inventory.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, the bid-ask spread element, is that most budget looking to share price, so it has to be narrowing now between what you guys would see us value and what sellers look?
componenttext: Sure. I mean, the bid-ask spread element, is that most budget looking to share price, so it has to be narrowing now between what you guys would see us value and what sellers look?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I mean, clearly bid-ask has to be a function of a number of factors, including the business climate, unique capabilities and assessments of individual investors. And certainly longer the commodity prices are in this area code, the more pressure
componenttext: Yes. Well, I mean, clearly bid-ask has to be a function of a number of factors, including the business climate, unique capabilities and assessments of individual investors. And certainly longer the commodity prices are in this area code, the more pressure will put on the bid-ask. But I think also, Paul, as you probably well aware, I mean the absence of any major deals absent a few couple one-offs really talks that there's still a gap to valuations. We'll be thoughtful. We'll make sure that anything that looks of interest is going to be value adding.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Indeed. And then a bit of a technical question. Does this person retire on his 65th birthday or at the beginning of 2017 typically? I mean what would be the model? I guess, what I'm driving at it is going to be his last Analyst Meeting?
componenttext: Indeed. And then a bit of a technical question. Does this person retire on his 65th birthday or at the beginning of 2017 typically? I mean what would be the model? I guess, what I'm driving at it is going to be his last Analyst Meeting?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Well, I mean, I'm not going to provide any specifics. I mean, that's really a function of the board's decision.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'd like to follow up a little more on your lower 48 you talked earlier about the rig count trying to maintain spending within a reasonable level of returns but balancing that against the maintaining the right amount of service sector capability
componenttext: I guess, I'd like to follow up a little more on your lower 48 you talked earlier about the rig count trying to maintain spending within a reasonable level of returns but balancing that against the maintaining the right amount of service sector capability and all. But as you look at lower 48 volume growth, which was certainly reasonable in the past year, does it grow in '16 at these levels? And I know you wouldn't necessarily start with the idea of growth, but does it grow at these levels?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I don't have any specifics to share with you right now. But I would tell you, think about this is that the choices that we are making are all based on value propositions. The outcome of those will be volumes. And as I indicated earlier, Roger, we'
componenttext: Yes. So I don't have any specifics to share with you right now. But I would tell you, think about this is that the choices that we are making are all based on value propositions. The outcome of those will be volumes. And as I indicated earlier, Roger, we've got a very deep portfolio of investment opportunities in the lower 48 particularly in the unconventional business. And we'll maintain an appropriate balance sheet of the short cycle investments. And when we feel like that the business climate supports it, we'll probably increase the amount of activity. I think what's important to note is that we are very well poised to flex the program up or down depending on the business climate.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that. The other question I had was on the share repo program, I understand taking it off the table for now. If you were to get a surprise influx of cash flow, just say higher commodity prices, is the decision of the near term that it would like
componenttext: Appreciate that. The other question I had was on the share repo program, I understand taking it off the table for now. If you were to get a surprise influx of cash flow, just say higher commodity prices, is the decision of the near term that it would likely go towards shareholder returns? Or is it CapEx would go up? And I know Mobil is not a quick trigger place like some other businesses, but you do have opportunities as you said in the lower 48. What sort of the internal thinking on that front?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, it was an influx of cash flow. I mean, I would tell you that it's going to be out function of the board's decision on a quarterly basis. I mean if we see supply and demand continuing to balance out, that may be a signal for us to modify our
componenttext: Well, I mean, it was an influx of cash flow. I mean, I would tell you that it's going to be out function of the board's decision on a quarterly basis. I mean if we see supply and demand continuing to balance out, that may be a signal for us to modify our investment plans going forward. But as I've indicated previously, Roger, the board makes the decision on a quarterly basis on what level of buybacks we want to maintain, and consider a whole range of factors, including the business climate in making that decision.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay, Powerball lottery by itself doesn't do it. You have to have some other fundamental helping you out?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, you've got a great year here of production. This is something where I'm sure we'll get more clarity in March. But can you just talk about $23 billion, how you think about the level of production relative to the 4.2 million barrels a day that you out
componenttext: Jeff, you've got a great year here of production. This is something where I'm sure we'll get more clarity in March. But can you just talk about $23 billion, how you think about the level of production relative to the 4.2 million barrels a day that you outlined last year for 2016? And then, broadly speaking, which regions where you would see potential changes?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Neil, let me just first just take an opportunity to acknowledge a very strong operational year in 2015, achieving the 4.1 million oil-equivalent barrels per day, which I just want to emphasize with the group, it's really an outcome of our value
componenttext: Yes. Well, Neil, let me just first just take an opportunity to acknowledge a very strong operational year in 2015, achieving the 4.1 million oil-equivalent barrels per day, which I just want to emphasize with the group, it's really an outcome of our value choices that we've made. The organization has really delivered on the timely start up of our major projects, which are a very key and significant contribution to our volumes this year. I'll say looking forward, as I alluded to in the prepared comments, we have 10 more large-scale, long life projects starting up over the next couple of years. The first -- the next tranche of that would be 6 of the 10 starting up in 2016, maintain a very strong focus on the high-value work program as well as operational reliability. Looking forward, we will be sharing more on the near-term investment plans and some thoughts on our volumes in the upcoming Analyst Meeting. But really, I don't have more specifics to share with you at this point.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that, Jeff. And obviously one of Exxon's key advantage this year is your balance sheet. In light of some of the comments from the ratings agencies, can you just talk about your commitment to your AAA rating here? And then, any perspective tha
componenttext: I appreciate that, Jeff. And obviously one of Exxon's key advantage this year is your balance sheet. In light of some of the comments from the ratings agencies, can you just talk about your commitment to your AAA rating here? And then, any perspective that you can provide around how that could change as ratings agencies think about their market outlook?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, Neil. And clearly, I mean it's topical for many in the energy sector. I think first and foremost, let me just be clear. I mean, we get value from the AAA credit rating in the business, whether it be access to financial markets or acces
componenttext: Yes, good question, Neil. And clearly, I mean it's topical for many in the energy sector. I think first and foremost, let me just be clear. I mean, we get value from the AAA credit rating in the business, whether it be access to financial markets or access to resources. I mean there's a benefit that we get from it, and we see it as being important. But it is really an outcome of our long-standing effective management of the business, including things like our strong balance sheet, the way we have prudently managed our cash, our disciplined investment and our leading financial and operating results, all of which has allowed us to financial flexibility to invest in the cycle as we've been discussing. I tell you that the current environment is clearly tough, but we've managed the business to be durable on the low end of commodity prices. We are very well positioned to continue the same level of secured performance in the future, and we think that all underpins the strong credit rating that we have.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: It looks like that the effective tax rate is 13% in the quarter. We understand the mix of earning, often times they impact the absolute level of that tax. componenttext: That was quarter-to-quarter, fourth quarter '15 and fourth quarter '14. The full year had a negative impact to our earnings about $125 million, that's ForEx, okay? headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Jeff, when you say that onetime tax item, 14% -- it seems like you're talking about 14% because you said 19% overall reduction, 5% is due to the mix of the asset, and so the onetime item is 14%. Is that 14% spread across different segments or just primarily in Upstream?

componenttext: I just had a question looking at production and declines. You put in place a couple of projects in Europe to potentially take advantage of the heavier feedstocks over time, it looks Antwerp being the primary one. headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the question on the Downstream because the organization has really performed tremendously in the year. Our investments in the Downstream, particularly in Europe are really focused on the following items. One, the increased feedstock flexib
componenttext: Yes, thanks for the question on the Downstream because the organization has really performed tremendously in the year. Our investments in the Downstream, particularly in Europe are really focused on the following items. One, the increased feedstock flexibility; the second is to increase logistics flexibility; the third one is to increase higher value product yields. I'll come back to that, and then the last and important one is fully capturing the integration value or manufacturing facilities and reducing our cost structure. On the higher value product yields, I mean, when we talk about Antwerp or Rotterdam, both are achieving the same objective. On Antwerp, we're converting bunker fuel oil into ultra-low sulfur diesel. Again, constructive on longer term supply/demand and in Rotterdam, we're converting VGO into premium group 2 basestocks and as well to low sulfur diesel.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, 2 points. On the near-term expectation of LNG, there's a number of projects some of which are already coming on line that are probably take us above demand for a period of time, say into 2020 to 2023 when the supply and demand will start com
componenttext: Yes, I guess, 2 points. On the near-term expectation of LNG, there's a number of projects some of which are already coming on line that are probably take us above demand for a period of time, say into 2020 to 2023 when the supply and demand will start coming -- coming to converge again. So clearly, I mean is going to have a pressure on those volumes that are trading on the spot market. Just to remind everybody, when we make an investment decision on these projects, we locked in our investment decisions on long-term contracts. Golden pass, we have submitted our formal application with FERC to construct and operate the project. We're working closely with federal agencies for completing the review process in 2016. The final investment decision will be made once we've gone through the government and regulatory approvals.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if -- given all the changes that we've seen in the oil markets over the last call it 18 months, has Exxon revised the range of prices that it uses to evaluate investment decisions?
componenttext: I wonder if -- given all the changes that we've seen in the oil markets over the last call it 18 months, has Exxon revised the range of prices that it uses to evaluate investment decisions?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say, Allen, that we continue to see that the range is applicable given our constructive view on supply and demand. We won't speculate on specific prices or differentials. We certainly expect the weakness, and so supply and demand comes back and
componenttext: Well, I'd say, Allen, that we continue to see that the range is applicable given our constructive view on supply and demand. We won't speculate on specific prices or differentials. We certainly expect the weakness, and so supply and demand comes back and the balance in the storage overhang is worked up. As I've said a few times, Allen, regardless of what the price is doing we're going to keep focus on those things that we control, which really translates into self-help margin.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then deepwater offshore, very big part of Exxon's portfolio getting bigger from what you've shared today. Can you give any indication as to what Exxon has seen with respect to either cost savings via equipment or services or maybe even cost savings un
componenttext: And then deepwater offshore, very big part of Exxon's portfolio getting bigger from what you've shared today. Can you give any indication as to what Exxon has seen with respect to either cost savings via equipment or services or maybe even cost savings under redesign certain projects that will ultimately lower the break evens and make them more competitive within your portfolio?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Really good question. There's a lot of different variables in this. One in terms of the quality of the resources and the certainty on the overall potential in those resources. Another one been how do we get the structural capital efficiency built in
componenttext: Yes. Really good question. There's a lot of different variables in this. One in terms of the quality of the resources and the certainty on the overall potential in those resources. Another one been how do we get the structural capital efficiency built in so that the economics are more robust. I'll highlight a couple of things. One in 2015, you'll recall in West Africa, we brought in, brought on 2 very capital efficient subsea tiebacks to insisting infrastructure. One being the Kizomba's satellite Phase 2 and being the other one [indiscernible] Phase 2 that allows us to leverage existing oil rich and develop the deepwater resources in a much more cost effective way. Clearly, there is a lot of opportunity to continue to standardize the subsea kit, but the organization is looking at all the levers to improve the economics of deepwater. In the Gulf of Mexico, I should note that Hadrian South was another example of efficient capital efficiency subsea tied back into existing infrastructure.

componenttext: Okay, that's fine. Many of your peers, Jeff, are restructuring, they're rightsizing or downsizing. Exxon has had anything news like so is there any plans in the works for do you feel that you have adequate workforce given your business model?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, John, I appreciate you asking it. Let me first say for the group's benefit that one of our greatest strengths are our people. And I think those of us that went through the lay offs in the '80s really learned some of the core lessons
componenttext: It's a good question, John, I appreciate you asking it. Let me first say for the group's benefit that one of our greatest strengths are our people. And I think those of us that went through the lay offs in the '80s really learned some of the core lessons about how those layouts significantly impaired organizational effectiveness. I mean since then, we have been very diligent in managing employee headcount given the cyclical nature of the business and in need, our organization to be ever more productive and at the same time, grow collective competency to meet the challenges in front of us. In doing so, I'd also say we're unrelenting on our focus at capturing efficiencies to make sure that we right size the organization. Again, given the likelihood of business volatility. I'd also highlight, John, that another benefit of our integrated business model is that we're able to be agile in redeploying personnel to segments of our business that are experiencing market strength or growth such as our Downstream and Chemical businesses right now. All that said, our employee headcount has been coming down consistently since the Exxon and Mobil merger. We're down about 35% during 2015. Over that time period, if you look at just the last 5 years, we're down about 20%. And I can -- just assured that the organizations continue to be focused on productivity enhancements and making sure that we're getting all the efficiencies out of the business.

componenttext: Good morning. I would tell you that certainly, given the downturn, there are more opportunities for us to consider. There is nothing that I can share with you specifically, but it does speak to the strength of ExxonMobil given that we've got the capability to invest in a down cycle, we bring a tremendous amount of operation, commercial and project expertise. So it allows us to be very selective as to what choices we want to pursue with a very strong focus on placing our attention on those areas that are have caused the existing producing infrastructure and those areas that have very high quality, large resource potential.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know this is a tough question to answer, but I'm interested in how you think about the strategically scale of the CapEx reductions we're seeing, how do you think about the sustainability of these lower organic spending levels with respect to being suffi
componenttext: I know this is a tough question to answer, but I'm interested in how you think about the strategically scale of the CapEx reductions we're seeing, how do you think about the sustainability of these lower organic spending levels with respect to being sufficient to drive the modest level of production great for the portfolio? You also replenished the resource base. Are you spending now below what you believe is sustainable? And how do you think about the balance between spending at a sustainable level versus perhaps racking lower to limit your outspent for a period of time?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would tell you, Guy, to really think about the decisions that we're making are really value-driven. The output is really the volumes, but it's really making the choices that are aligned with creating value in the portfolio, whether it be in the Ups
componenttext: Yes. I would tell you, Guy, to really think about the decisions that we're making are really value-driven. The output is really the volumes, but it's really making the choices that are aligned with creating value in the portfolio, whether it be in the Upstream or the Downstream or Chemical business, recognizing that we've got this integration, this very strong integration across our portfolio that we can create value through the whole value chain. So the choices are really focused on making sure that we're creating incremental value. The volumes will be an output of that.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I talked a little bit earlier about underlying demand growth has been over 1 million barrels a day, so it's been a little bit higher than what we've seen over the 10-year average. If you think about where we are today, we're about 1.5 million barrel
componenttext: Well, I talked a little bit earlier about underlying demand growth has been over 1 million barrels a day, so it's been a little bit higher than what we've seen over the 10-year average. If you think about where we are today, we're about 1.5 million barrels a day oversupplied in the first half. We do expect that to converge in the second half with seasonal demand growth. So you think about the impact on prices in the near term, it's really going to be a function of how that supply/demand converges and of course, working off the storage overhang that's been built up over the last couple of years. That's all about I can share at this point.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you. To conclude, again, I'd like to thank you for your time and your questions. I just want to step back for a moment and take stock of 2015 and say, the organization really did a very significant -- to provide a very significant result when
componenttext: Well, thank you. To conclude, again, I'd like to thank you for your time and your questions. I just want to step back for a moment and take stock of 2015 and say, the organization really did a very significant -- to provide a very significant result when you think about positive free cash flow, very effective cost management, lowering our spending that have bottom line impacts, benefits to the business, our excellence in project execution and are delivering long life, long plateau volumes that benefits of integrated business model across the value chain, the financial strength of the organization investing through the commodity price cycle. And of course, our dividend growth, continuing to share the success of the company. And I think that just points to the strong business fundamentals based on our proven track record. We'll talk more about this in March, but we do appreciate your interest in ExxonMobil, and we certainly look forward to meeting with you next month.
