componenttext: Yes. On the mix side, I'd tell you, it always has to do with the relative contribution between U.S., international, between Upstream, Downstream and our Chemical businesses. And you can just sense from my comments that there's a lot of complexity in that. In terms of what to expect going forward, what I'd say is if we were talking about 2015 commodity prices, our guidance would stay at an effective tax rate of between 35% to 40%. Now if we're in a lower commodity price environment like we saw in the first quarter, we're probably looking at something less than 30%.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Second question is just maybe a follow-up on the balance sheet. Looking at it slightly differently, your absolute debt levels are now around $43 billion. I'm just kind of wondering how you feel about that comfort-wise as you look thr
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Second question is just maybe a follow-up on the balance sheet. Looking at it slightly differently, your absolute debt levels are now around $43 billion. I'm just kind of wondering how you feel about that comfort-wise as you look through the cycle? In a better environment with more cash flow, is that paid down on an absolute basis in any way a priority? Or would you be thinking about other uses of cash?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we'll -- obviously one of the considerations when we think about our capital allocation is retirement of debt. So we'll keep mindful. But remember, we've got a very strong balance sheet. We will look at the relative decisions around investme
componenttext: Well, I mean, we'll -- obviously one of the considerations when we think about our capital allocation is retirement of debt. So we'll keep mindful. But remember, we've got a very strong balance sheet. We will look at the relative decisions around investments in the business, the pace of investments, our commitment to our reliable and growing dividend and then appropriately, consideration on long-term debt levels. It's all about maintaining prudent cash management, maintaining our financial flexibility. We're going to be continue to be disciplined in our investment approach. We're not going to forego attractive opportunities, but we'll continue to assess our cash and our funding operations options around a range of options and take a very balanced approach on how we go forward in our capital deployment.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify, would debt paydown be a priority over buybacks?
componenttext: Just to clarify, would debt paydown be a priority over buybacks?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I really -- that's a decision that will be taken by the board, that will be function of a lot of factors, Phil. I wouldn't leave you with any impression that there's any prioritization that I'm conveying.
componenttext: Yes, I really -- that's a decision that will be taken by the board, that will be function of a lot of factors, Phil. I wouldn't leave you with any impression that there's any prioritization that I'm conveying.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this -- I have 2 questions. The first one may be a little bit more detail and -- just let me know. If we're looking at the economics, have you talked to your Downstream people that whether why now is economic to bring naphtha into the U.S. gasoline
componenttext: Jeff, this -- I have 2 questions. The first one may be a little bit more detail and -- just let me know. If we're looking at the economics, have you talked to your Downstream people that whether why now is economic to bring naphtha into the U.S. gasoline pool? Or that you're better off to ship naphtha into your cracker for the petrochemical in Europe or Asia?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you -- Paul, are you asking about bringing naphtha...
componenttext: Are you -- Paul, are you asking about bringing naphtha...

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: From U.S.
componenttext: From U.S.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Importing it into our -- into the U.S.?
componenttext: Importing it into our -- into the U.S.?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Exporting from U.S. either because, I mean, we -- [indiscernible] Shell oil not every still have excess naphtha in this country. So the question that I have is have you discussed it with your refining and chemical colleague that whether it's more
componenttext: No, no. Exporting from U.S. either because, I mean, we -- [indiscernible] Shell oil not every still have excess naphtha in this country. So the question that I have is have you discussed it with your refining and chemical colleague that whether it's more economic for them to take the naive naphtha directly bring it into the gasoline pool in the U.S. or that you export it into the overseas, such as in your European or in your Asia petrochemical guy to use it as a feedstock there?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we maintain tremendous flexibility on our feedstock options. And that's a real-time optimization that we're managing. And we'll optimize those feeds based on the best available returns. That's moving -- that's including moving feeds between continent
componenttext: Yes, we maintain tremendous flexibility on our feedstock options. And that's a real-time optimization that we're managing. And we'll optimize those feeds based on the best available returns. That's moving -- that's including moving feeds between continents.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but just curious, I mean, do you have any kind of insight that you can share at this point that -- how's the economics, the ship? Is it more in favor of branding into the gasoline pool in this country or just exporting?
componenttext: Yes, but just curious, I mean, do you have any kind of insight that you can share at this point that -- how's the economics, the ship? Is it more in favor of branding into the gasoline pool in this country or just exporting?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, I really don't have anything else to share on it other than to say that it's a dynamic issue that we continue to optimize. And I'd say that we are very well positioned to ensure that we're making the best value choices with respect to our feeds
componenttext: Yes, Paul, I really don't have anything else to share on it other than to say that it's a dynamic issue that we continue to optimize. And I'd say that we are very well positioned to ensure that we're making the best value choices with respect to our feedstocks slate.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second question is that for the Point Thomson, you mentioned in your prepared remarks and also gave you a platform or a demonstration for potentially in the future, Alaska LNG Project. Let's assume that the Alaska LNG Project won't go ahead and it's r
componenttext: The second question is that for the Point Thomson, you mentioned in your prepared remarks and also gave you a platform or a demonstration for potentially in the future, Alaska LNG Project. Let's assume that the Alaska LNG Project won't go ahead and it's really not economic at all, is the Point Thomson still a good investment in here by yourself without that purpose?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you, Paul, that we look at these decisions on a long term. And given the constructive view, what we think gas is going to do over time, we are confident that the Alaska gas will be commercialized. As to how that actually happens may vary
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you, Paul, that we look at these decisions on a long term. And given the constructive view, what we think gas is going to do over time, we are confident that the Alaska gas will be commercialized. As to how that actually happens may vary from what we're currently considering, but we have been very active with our partners in the state to identify the highest-value opportunity in order to commercialize that gas. And it's going to compete on a global perspective. What's going to be really critical is getting transparent, predictable and stable fiscal structure in place in order to make sure that it underpins such a significant investment.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could share a little bit about the rationale of the dividend increase. I know during your Analyst Day you kind of provided a cash flow breakeven potential in 2017. It sounded like during your remarks today, you had kind of alluded to some
componenttext: I was hoping you could share a little bit about the rationale of the dividend increase. I know during your Analyst Day you kind of provided a cash flow breakeven potential in 2017. It sounded like during your remarks today, you had kind of alluded to some capital efficiency and maybe potential for capital to be moving down. So I didn't know if it would be fair to think that, that cash flow breakeven number has potential to potentially move down and maybe if that played into your thoughts around the dividend increase?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when you're referring to the cash flow neutrality slide that we shared with you during the analyst presentation. And if you recall, it's just a -- it's a perspective of how we're managing our cash and how we manage the business. And the organ
componenttext: Yes, I think when you're referring to the cash flow neutrality slide that we shared with you during the analyst presentation. And if you recall, it's just a -- it's a perspective of how we're managing our cash and how we manage the business. And the organization is always trying to reduce that cost structure and improve the ultimate margins. And you're correct. I mean, we had a -- we feel fairly confident that we can achieve cash flow neutrality into the future. I mean, what we shared with you during the Analyst Meeting was a very wide range on prices, but one that's reasonable with the low end being $40 flat real. And you can see that we have good potential to reach that cash flow neutrality, particularly in 2017 forward. As I said earlier, we continue to reduce our cash expenditures and making good gains. But I would tell you that when we make the decisions around capital allocation, it's a consideration of a lot of factors. We're going to balance our long-term investment with our shareholder distributions. Nothing has changed, but I'll tell you that we remain very committed to that reliable and growing dividend.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. The second one is just kind of project specific. I know you mentioned Kashigan coming online later this year. I think there have been some press reports suggesting that could get pushed out to '17. Can you remind me, I believe Exxon was slate
componenttext: Okay. Great. The second one is just kind of project specific. I know you mentioned Kashigan coming online later this year. I think there have been some press reports suggesting that could get pushed out to '17. Can you remind me, I believe Exxon was slated to take over operatorship. Are you formally controlling the news flow on that? Or are you relying on peers at this point?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the Kashigan is managed by the North Caspian Operating Company, and which you may recall hearing us that was restructured in a more conventional manner. And ExxonMobil seconded the director for NCOC. In terms of timing, what we're doing there is we're
componenttext: No, the Kashigan is managed by the North Caspian Operating Company, and which you may recall hearing us that was restructured in a more conventional manner. And ExxonMobil seconded the director for NCOC. In terms of timing, what we're doing there is we're replacing the onshore, offshore gas and oil pipelines where NCOC is. And they're making good progress. They're progressing as per plan with the intention to complete that by the end of this year and start up the facility.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Asit Sen from CLSA Americas.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Asit Sen from CLSA Americas.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two Upstream questions, one on Upper Zakum and one on West Africa. On Upper Zakum and Abu Dhabi, Jeff, there were talks to expand capacity to over 1 million barrels a day. Could you update us on the current thought process on expansion and where productio
componenttext: Two Upstream questions, one on Upper Zakum and one on West Africa. On Upper Zakum and Abu Dhabi, Jeff, there were talks to expand capacity to over 1 million barrels a day. Could you update us on the current thought process on expansion and where production is currently? And secondly, on West Africa, Exxon had decent success last year in starting up new projects, Kizomba in Angola and Erha in Nigeria. How would you characterize the current operating environment in some of the key countries given all the reported fiscals for us? I know it's probably a general comment, but any color would be helpful.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, Asit. On Upper Zakum, current production is around 500 -- or 650,000 barrels a day. Its -- the project itself is progressing well to increase capacity ultimately to 750,000 barrels a day. We are continuing to evaluate the opportunity to expand
componenttext: Yes. Okay, Asit. On Upper Zakum, current production is around 500 -- or 650,000 barrels a day. Its -- the project itself is progressing well to increase capacity ultimately to 750,000 barrels a day. We are continuing to evaluate the opportunity to expand to a 1 million-barrel a day development. So really nothing more to share on that.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, on the time frame for 750,000 is what? What time frame?
componenttext: And Jeff, on the time frame for 750,000 is what? What time frame?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Getting up to that full 750,000?
componenttext: Getting up to that full 750,000?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't recall -- by -- probably around by 2018. On West Africa, like you said, we've made some really good progress. But just a broad comment about -- globally there -- with the country budgets feeling the strain of low energy prices, it is slowing d
componenttext:
I don't recall -- by -- probably around by 2018.
 
On West Africa, like you said, we've made some really good progress. But just a broad comment about -- globally there -- with the country budgets feeling the strain of low energy prices, it is slowing down investment globally. And that is a challenge, to make sure that we progress those investments at a pace that is consistent with the resource owner. I'll say that we have a very strong inventory of opportunities in West Africa, but we've got a do it consistent with the confidence in the fiscal basis in which we're making those investments.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guess, if we could talk maybe a little bit about cost deflation kind of where you're progressing, both on the CapEx and the OpEx side and whether kind of consistent with one of the questions asked earlier if there was any seasonal component to that, that
componenttext: Guess, if we could talk maybe a little bit about cost deflation kind of where you're progressing, both on the CapEx and the OpEx side and whether kind of consistent with one of the questions asked earlier if there was any seasonal component to that, that we should be thinking about?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so just a recap for the results that we had last year, we were able to reduce our total CapEx and cash OpEx by about $16 billion year-on-year, representing about a 16% decrease. In terms of going forward in 2016, nothing's really changed. We continue
componenttext: Yes, so just a recap for the results that we had last year, we were able to reduce our total CapEx and cash OpEx by about $16 billion year-on-year, representing about a 16% decrease. In terms of going forward in 2016, nothing's really changed. We continue to manage the cost side, as we always have, focusing on structural efficiencies, market savings while maintaining operational integrity. I'll tell you, Roger, we still believe there's significant opportunity in streamlining the business and reducing the cost structure. And I'd say it's -- while it's early in the year, we're seeing a similar trend line as to last year. But we will maintain that relentless focus on cost, regardless of whether we're in a low-price environment or in a high-price environment. Just to give you a bit of a perspective, again, being very early in the year, our Upstream unit costs for OpEx are down about 9%.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. That's helpful. And along those same lines, at this point, oil prices have rebounded. The market's starting to think about an ultimate recovery in drilling activity. Do you take advantage? I mean, consistent with your view on there's lot more
componenttext: Okay. Great. That's helpful. And along those same lines, at this point, oil prices have rebounded. The market's starting to think about an ultimate recovery in drilling activity. Do you take advantage? I mean, consistent with your view on there's lot more costs to get out. Is this a point at which you'd want to sign contracts, kind of lock in service capacity, service pricing kind of anywhere around the world really?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I would say, Roger, that in the downturn, we have been high-grading our service providers and we've been locking in more favorable, more efficient service contracts. So it's not something that we had stopped doing. I mean, one of the advanta
componenttext: Well, I mean, I would say, Roger, that in the downturn, we have been high-grading our service providers and we've been locking in more favorable, more efficient service contracts. So it's not something that we had stopped doing. I mean, one of the advantages of ExxonMobil is that we're able to invest through the cycle. That means that in a down cycle, we're continuing to spend a significant amount of money to capture value opportunities associated with that down cycle. So of course, the organization, and you've heard me talk previously, Roger, about the global procurement business. But it's all focused around finding the lowest life cycle cost. And you're correct to say that in a low-price environment, there are some unique opportunities that we want to walk into.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So clearly $48 Brent is not a great price, but it's a heck of a lot better than $30 a barrel Brent. And so it feels like this market is moving in the right direction. Demand is growing and we're seeing signs on OPEC supplies coming offline. I just want to
componenttext: So clearly $48 Brent is not a great price, but it's a heck of a lot better than $30 a barrel Brent. And so it feels like this market is moving in the right direction. Demand is growing and we're seeing signs on OPEC supplies coming offline. I just want to reconcile that with your view -- or does Exxon believe that we are starting to see the signs of a sustained recovery in energy prices, particularly crude? And then because you get to see the world through your portfolio, one of the big debates is on a OPEC supply outside the U.S. really rolling over because of the decline rates. Are you seeing evidence that, that supply outside the U.S. is actually falling off?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the first thing I'd say, Neil, it's really a good thought around how the macro is looking and how the sector will respond to it. I'd say, first and foremost is that remember, we are price takers. We are not counting on price growth. What we are focus
componenttext: Yes, the first thing I'd say, Neil, it's really a good thought around how the macro is looking and how the sector will respond to it. I'd say, first and foremost is that remember, we are price takers. We are not counting on price growth. What we are focused on is really maintaining a focus on the things that we control in order to create margin. So regardless what it's going to do, it's going to do it. And we're going to keep focused on the things that we control. Second thing I'd say, and it's just a little more expansion from what I was sharing with Doug earlier, is that underlying demand growth has been generally strong. And we expect this year will be in excess of the 10-year average. Now I would say that in the first half of 2016, we're still oversupplied by about 1.5 million barrels per day. We do expect to see convergence in the second half with seasonal demand growth, but that's going to widen again in the first half of 2017. And remember, during this period of oversupply, we've been building up commercial inventories since about year-end 2013. So thinking forward, we are seeing a convergence over supply and demand into the future, but we've got this overhead of supply that's going to also have to work off over time. So we're heading in the right direction. In terms of how and when that will happen will be anybody's guess. Remember, there's still a fair bit of uncertainty in terms of the supply trend and the economic growth near term. But clearly we're seeing, as you are all aware, we're seeing North America supply dropping off pretty significantly now.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then 2 questions -- related questions here. First, is any update on Torrance? And then second what's the latest on Groningen?
componenttext: And then 2 questions -- related questions here. First, is any update on Torrance? And then second what's the latest on Groningen?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on Torrance, we have completed the repairs of the electrostatic precipitator and that we have received the approval from the regulator to go ahead and start operations. So there's a number of things that we need to do to get it up and capacity dem
componenttext: Yes, so on Torrance, we have completed the repairs of the electrostatic precipitator and that we have received the approval from the regulator to go ahead and start operations. So there's a number of things that we need to do to get it up and capacity demonstrated, but we do expect the formal change in control to happen mid-2016.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Groningen?
componenttext: In Groningen?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Groningen, as you know, we have a pretty -- continue to have a pretty significant impact on volumes in the quarter. It was close to 600 million cubic feet a day. We have made our -- NAM has made the submission for the new production forecast going forw
componenttext: On Groningen, as you know, we have a pretty -- continue to have a pretty significant impact on volumes in the quarter. It was close to 600 million cubic feet a day. We have made our -- NAM has made the submission for the new production forecast going forward. And my understanding is that the regulator will review that by September of this year. Right now, the cap is at 27 billion cubic meters, but it has the potential to grow up, depending on what demand requirements are.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I was looking back at the interview that Rex Tillerson gave after the Analyst Meeting when he was asked about the AAA rating. And what he said quite specifically is that there's been periods where Exxon's financial metrics have been worse than they
componenttext: Jeff, I was looking back at the interview that Rex Tillerson gave after the Analyst Meeting when he was asked about the AAA rating. And what he said quite specifically is that there's been periods where Exxon's financial metrics have been worse than they are today, but you still retain the AAA rating. And obviously, as you mentioned in your remarks, you have been downgraded by S&P. Naturally, I went to S&P and what I saw there was the comment that maintaining production and replacing reserves will require higher spending from Exxon. So it seems that given the financial metrics and not the issue that it seem -- there's an Upstream issue that S&P is concerned about. Can you talk about your ability to maintain production and reserves at the current level of spending and address whether or not they're correct in thinking that you are going to have to spend a lot more to maintain reserves and production?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. Well, first, I'd remind everybody that we've got a very large inventory of investment opportunities, over 90 billion barrels of resource in our portfolio. And if you'll recall in the analyst presentation, we provide a little bit more insight a
componenttext: Sure, Paul. Well, first, I'd remind everybody that we've got a very large inventory of investment opportunities, over 90 billion barrels of resource in our portfolio. And if you'll recall in the analyst presentation, we provide a little bit more insight as to the type of projects and their potential capacity they can bring on over the time horizon. Now of course, what we need to do is we need to make sure that as we mature, the inventory projects that we're doing it with the greatest value proposition. And I think we've made great strides in finding unique opportunities in order to reduce the cost structure going forward. I'd say, though, Paul that we've been through these cycles for a long time. We've been able to maintain a very strong balance sheet. We've maintained our financial flexibility through the ups and downs, and our inventory looks very attractive going forward. So we think all the elements are set right to continue to invest in an attractive way to maintain our industry-leading return on capital employed. The other point I'd remind you is that as we showed in the analyst presentation, we have done very well in terms of efficiency of deploying investment dollars. If you recall, the Upstream capital efficiency chart that we used in the analyst presentation showing our capital employed over proved reserves, clearly we're distinguishing ourselves relative to others.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Jeff, because of time constraints, I'll just jump on to the other one. You again mentioned return on capital employed. I really struggle with you losing money in the Upstream on an earnings basis, particularly in the U.S. and how you reconcile that
componenttext: Okay. Jeff, because of time constraints, I'll just jump on to the other one. You again mentioned return on capital employed. I really struggle with you losing money in the Upstream on an earnings basis, particularly in the U.S. and how you reconcile that with the measure that's on the capital employed. Typically, we don't look at that. We look at the cash flow measure. Can you help us with the DD&A Upstream, particularly in the U.S., so that we can get to the cash returns that you're making as opposed to these losses Upstream?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've got a very strong portfolio in the Upstream. And remember that we invest with a long-term view that's informed by our long-term energy demand outlook. All of our assets are managed to maximize returns through the life cycle with the objective o
componenttext: Yes, we've got a very strong portfolio in the Upstream. And remember that we invest with a long-term view that's informed by our long-term energy demand outlook. All of our assets are managed to maximize returns through the life cycle with the objective of maintaining positive cash flow in low-price environments. We'll continue to focus on those things that we control: Cost, reliability, operational integrity. Importantly, we'll invest in attractive opportunities throughout the cycle that further enhance the asset profitability. And we see significant value in our assets. So, yes, there is a low-price -- we're in a low-price period, like we've been in the past. As I've said, we've really designed these assets to be very durable during a low-price environment. It continue to generate -- our producing assets continue to generate cash flow. And over the long term, we will continue to demonstrate industry-leading returns on capital employed.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Anish Kapadia from Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Anish Kapadia from Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have a question on project execution. I think Exxon is clearly showing leadership amongst your peers on project execution over the last few years, but Exxon doesn't seem to have sanctioned any major Upstream projects of note over the last couple of
componenttext: I just have a question on project execution. I think Exxon is clearly showing leadership amongst your peers on project execution over the last few years, but Exxon doesn't seem to have sanctioned any major Upstream projects of note over the last couple of years and don't see anything on the horizon to be sanctioned for this year. So I'm just wondering how do you intend to benefit from the quality of your project execution if you're not progressing with projects at the moment?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks for the question, Anish. I'd tell you that we will announce our FIDs after the company's made that funding decision, so we really don't project it. But as I indicated just a moment ago, we gave you the insight through our analyst presentation
componenttext: Well, thanks for the question, Anish. I'd tell you that we will announce our FIDs after the company's made that funding decision, so we really don't project it. But as I indicated just a moment ago, we gave you the insight through our analyst presentation and the F&O as to the type of projects that we're currently working on. And we've really taken this down cycle as an opportunity to retest the value proposition for each one of these investment opportunities. And there are some incremental benefits that we're able to capture through -- anywhere from design changes to different ways to execute the project given the service market, to fiscal basis. So this is a good opportunity to step back and make sure that we're really capturing the most value from these investments. So we gave you some line of sight on the Upstream and I'll just remind you that we've got 10 major projects still underway in the Upstream. That will start up between 2016 and 2017 as well as we maintain a very active high-value work program, and we gave you some insight on that during the analyst presentation as well, with a very deep inventory of opportunities. So in summary, I'd tell you large inventory of investment opportunities that are in various stages of planning execution. When we get to the point when we've made an investment decision, we'll share that publicly. But the pace will be consistent upon project maturity to maximize value and our prudent financial management. And then, of course, remember, Anish, that we've got a lot of -- a number of very large investments underway in our Downstream and Chemical business.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one follow-up. Most specifically on Nigeria because you've got a number of projects that are a bit -- have been in your project queue for a number of years. The satellite field project that you've gave, [indiscernible]. And I see you've add
componenttext: Okay. And just one follow-up. Most specifically on Nigeria because you've got a number of projects that are a bit -- have been in your project queue for a number of years. The satellite field project that you've gave, [indiscernible]. And I see you've added yet another project, a way, way west into that project queue. Just wondering what's kind of prevented you from sanctioning some of those projects that's been around for a long time? What needs to change in Nigeria for you to be able to go ahead with the projects?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd tell you that some of these projects are a function of optimizing the design all the way through to getting alignment with partners and establishing the right fiscal basis to go ahead and make that investment.
componenttext: Yes, I'd tell you that some of these projects are a function of optimizing the design all the way through to getting alignment with partners and establishing the right fiscal basis to go ahead and make that investment.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Edward Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Edward Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on gas. We've got oversupplied markets in the U.S., in Europe and in Asia. Now clearly the best cure for gas prices being low is low gas prices demand will probably pick up as a result over time. But can you give us some sense of the magnitude of pot
componenttext: Just on gas. We've got oversupplied markets in the U.S., in Europe and in Asia. Now clearly the best cure for gas prices being low is low gas prices demand will probably pick up as a result over time. But can you give us some sense of the magnitude of potential gas declines across the portfolio as you exercise capital to spend over the next 4 or 5 years?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're talking with respect to our portfolio, Ed?
componenttext: Yes, you're talking with respect to our portfolio, Ed?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I'm really thinking about base business. I mean, obviously, we know that you've got some new projects coming on stream, [indiscernible], et cetera.
componenttext: Yes, and I'm really thinking about base business. I mean, obviously, we know that you've got some new projects coming on stream, [indiscernible], et cetera.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and you've seen in our volumes -- our gas volumes have dropped off in part and largely in the U.S. But in part, that is due to a switch from gas drilling to higher-value liquids drilling during this down cycle. Gas, Ed, we continue to be very constru
componenttext: Yes, and you've seen in our volumes -- our gas volumes have dropped off in part and largely in the U.S. But in part, that is due to a switch from gas drilling to higher-value liquids drilling during this down cycle. Gas, Ed, we continue to be very constructive, growing at about 1.6% per year, primarily driven by the power sector. LNG, we expect to triple from current capacity between now and 2040. So I think we've got the long-term value proposition well within our sight. And it's just pacing those investments consistent with that demand growth to make sure that we capture full value for it, but we've got a very deep inventory of gas. And if you look at our proved reserves, it's somewhere around 45% to 48% of our total proved reserves comparable part on our resource base. And then, of course, importantly, it adds significant value to the value chain. It provides an advantaged feedstock for us for our steam cracking here in North America. You may recall that we're in the progress of progressing the expansion over at Baytown for adding another 1.5 million tons per annum of cracking capacity. And in conjunction with that, adding polyethylene lines over at Mont Belvieu. So it's got a significant component of our future, very deep inventory, pace will be a function of demand.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe specific on Asia gas. You went from 4.1 down to 3.8 in the quarter. Could you mention PFC impacts in gas? I mean, maybe just run through what's happening there. Is it sort of customers are exercising low GCQs [ph] on the LNG contracts? Or is it some
componenttext: Maybe specific on Asia gas. You went from 4.1 down to 3.8 in the quarter. Could you mention PFC impacts in gas? I mean, maybe just run through what's happening there. Is it sort of customers are exercising low GCQs [ph] on the LNG contracts? Or is it something else there?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: There were 3 major drivers there. One was plant maintenance. Second one being asset management, some divestments, and the third one being price impacts.
componenttext: There were 3 major drivers there. One was plant maintenance. Second one being asset management, some divestments, and the third one being price impacts.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're not seeing customers exercise low quantity [indiscernible]?
componenttext: So you're not seeing customers exercise low quantity [indiscernible]?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I really can't talk about specific contracts, but it's primarily driven by the 3 items that I shared with you.
componenttext: Well, I mean, I really can't talk about specific contracts, but it's primarily driven by the 3 items that I shared with you.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Iain Reid from Macquarie.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Iain Reid from Macquarie.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions for you. You talked about the North American U.S. lower 48 liquid production's falling. But ExxonMobil's production isn't falling. It's going up. Is this kind of deliberate decision to invest kind of for cyclically, you talked about yo
componenttext: Couple of questions for you. You talked about the North American U.S. lower 48 liquid production's falling. But ExxonMobil's production isn't falling. It's going up. Is this kind of deliberate decision to invest kind of for cyclically, you talked about your long-term vision, et cetera? Or is it something specific to your acreage where you're getting more barrels out of your existing wells? Because you're contributing to the problem rather than the solution if you're growing your lower 48 volumes. And I got a follow-up after that.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'd tell you, Iain, that, as I said earlier, that we're continue to invest in the down cycle, and that provides an opportunity for us to capture lower cost structure in the investments that we're making. So particularly in the lower 48 unconventionals
componenttext: And I'd tell you, Iain, that, as I said earlier, that we're continue to invest in the down cycle, and that provides an opportunity for us to capture lower cost structure in the investments that we're making. So particularly in the lower 48 unconventionals, it's allowed us to high-grade the rig activity. We're down quite significantly in terms of our peak rigs. We're in excess of 60. Now we're down to about 16. So we have reduced our activity materially, but we continue to pursue the attractive unconventional opportunities that we have, predominantly in the Permian and Bakken. And we're getting great value for it. So it just shows the value proposition that ExxonMobil is able to provide because we have the capability to invest through the cycle.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up question is on Chemicals. Obviously, very strong numbers in this quarter. The environment is obviously pretty favorable out there in terms of natural gas prices as feedstock and also the fact that there's a lot of maintenance activi
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up question is on Chemicals. Obviously, very strong numbers in this quarter. The environment is obviously pretty favorable out there in terms of natural gas prices as feedstock and also the fact that there's a lot of maintenance activities out there. So lower production, but looking a little bit further forward, those items are going to correct. There's actually more volumes coming on stream. In fact, you're building capacity as well. So do you see this kind of Chemical cycle at the peak now? And then going into a little bit of a trough with second half this year and into next year? Or does Exxon have kind of a more kind of positive view of the market?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, currently, olefins and polyolefins have been pretty tight. And demand is continuing to grow and it's outpacing capacity additions. And I think that's an important investment opportunity. Remember, this is all our investment decisions, Iain, a
componenttext: Yes, I mean, currently, olefins and polyolefins have been pretty tight. And demand is continuing to grow and it's outpacing capacity additions. And I think that's an important investment opportunity. Remember, this is all our investment decisions, Iain, are really founded on our view of long-term demand. And on the Chemical side, as I mentioned earlier, we expect demand to grow about 1.5% above GDP. Now I'll tell you that the underlying demand growth across the olefins, polyolefins, the aromatics, our specialty has been fairly robust. Now sometimes, the supply capacity additions are outpacing that, and that's what you've seen, for instance, in paraxylene. But broadly speaking, the demand is robust and it's going to continue to grow, and we think it presents some investment opportunities.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Even with a growth in ethylene supply that we're looking at in the U.S. over the next year or so?
componenttext: Even with a growth in ethylene supply that we're looking at in the U.S. over the next year or so?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have time for one last question, and that will come from John Herrlin from Societe Generale.
componenttext: And we have time for one last question, and that will come from John Herrlin from Societe Generale.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one for me, Jeff, on Guyana. You have multiple structures in your lease area. In the event that you have multiple successes, should we consider Guyana to be kind of an analog to what you did in Kizomba awhile back in terms of design one, buil
componenttext: Just a quick one for me, Jeff, on Guyana. You have multiple structures in your lease area. In the event that you have multiple successes, should we consider Guyana to be kind of an analog to what you did in Kizomba awhile back in terms of design one, build many? And then my other question is can you bring some of these longer-cycle projects forward to take advantage of excess E&C capacity today? I mean, you did discuss kind of how you're optimizing things, but can you bring longer-cycle projects forward to take advantage of lower cost environment?

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. On Guyana, John, I'd tell you that as I indicated earlier, it is really early days, and we need to get a better handle of the full block potential. But kind of the question around design one build many, I mean, we're doing that across all of our
componenttext: Yes, yes. On Guyana, John, I'd tell you that as I indicated earlier, it is really early days, and we need to get a better handle of the full block potential. But kind of the question around design one build many, I mean, we're doing that across all of our businesses. And I'd tell you, the real modifier in that is design it once, but continue to get more and more efficient in that design and reduce the cost structure. So it's a -- I would tell you, to even expand it globally in terms of how you look at concurrent developments in different parts of the world to make sure that you're fully capturing the benefits of a robust design and execution. To your point around the engineering and construction contractors, yes, I mean, their backlogs are certainly light. And we are very mindful about pacing the investments to make sure that we maximize value. But we want to do it with a clear view on prudent financial management and maintaining our financial flexibility going forward. But I'd tell you that one of the best opportunities that we have out there is the collaboration that we've been able to have with many of our providers and really encouraging them to bring forward lower-cost solutions to see if we can make investments move quicker.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. Mr. Woodbury, at this time, I will turn the conference back to you for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. Mr. Woodbury, at this time, I will turn the conference back to you for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Exxon Mobil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you. To conclude, I just want to thank you all again for your time and very good questions. It was an insightful discussion, I think, for all of us. So we appreciate your time this morning, and we very much appreciate your interest in ExxonMob
componenttext: Well, thank you. To conclude, I just want to thank you all again for your time and very good questions. It was an insightful discussion, I think, for all of us. So we appreciate your time this morning, and we very much appreciate your interest in ExxonMobil, and we look forward to talking more with you in the future. Thank you.
